The inferiority of number was, however, corn- pensated by the advantage of the ground. Constantine had taken post in a defile about half a mile in breadth‚ between a steep hill and a deep morast, and in that situation he steadily expected and repulsed the first attack of the enemy. He pursued his success, and advanced into the plain. But the veteran legions of Illyricum rallied under the standard of a leader who had been trained to arms in the school of Probus and Diocletian. The miffile weapons on both fides were soon exhausted ; the two armies, with equal valour, rushed to a closer engagement of swords and spears, and the doubt- ful contest had already Iasted from the dawn os? day to alate hour of the evening‚ when the right wing, which Constantine led in person, made a vigorous and decisive charge.
